member.name: T:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Events.Monitors.DesignChangeResultsComplete
member.summary: This event is fired after all the results from a solve have been added as a design change. For example, if we have 3 calculators for a structural simulation, all three calculator results are returned from the solve and each adds a result to the design change, which raises a . At the end of those events, we expect this event to fire meaning the results are updated.

member.summary: shortcut check to see if there are any nonnegative thresholds

member.summary: uses the order of the groups in the tree hierarchy to define the order of the nodes

member.name: P:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Contracts.StructureTree.ITreeGrouping.CountIndirectChildren
member.summary: If true, counts direct non-group children and counts each direct subgroup child as its indirect children, else counts each direct subgroup as 1

member.name: P:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Contracts.StructureTree.ITreeGrouping.IgnoreThresholdAfterFirstSubGroup
member.summary: when true, groups will ignore its threshold and will form immediately if it contains a subgroup and anything else. This will NOT happen if the group in question has a negative threshold

member.name: P:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Contracts.StructureTree.ITreeGrouping.UseDeepGrouping
member.summary: when true, grouping will be applied to the children of every node in the tree instead of just the root node

member.summary: sets the threshold for a specific group
member.param: specific group to set the threshold of

minimum number of items required to form a group
value of 0 or 1 groups immediately
value of -1 or lower never groups

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Contracts.StructureTree.ITreeGrouping.ClearThresholdOverrides
member.summary: remove all threshold overrides, making the default threshold apply to all groups

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Contracts.StructureTree.ITreeGrouping.GetGroupingThreshold(System.String)
member.summary: returns the effective grouping threshold for the given group. The values of threshold overrides and will be used in the calculation
member.returns: the minimum group size for the group

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Contracts.StructureTree.ITreeGrouping.DefineCodependentSiblingGroups(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String},System.Int32)
member.summary: Defines a set of sibling groups which are not created unless a certain number of them are present (sibling threshold). ex: given groups A, B, and C with a sibling threshold of 2: A will never appear unless B or C is also present. given groups A, B, and C with a sibling threshold of 3: A, B, and C must all be present for any of them to appear.
member.param: the list of groups that are codependent
the minimum number of siblings that must be present in order for them to appear
member.returns: returns false if the list includes groups that are not direct children of the same parent node or the sibling threshold is greater than the number of siblings listed or less than 2

member.summary: Group all nodes passed in, using the supplied function to build the group nodes themselves

member.name: P:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.Conditions.BearingLoadEntity.LoadAngle
member.summary: Rotation in the plane defined by a normal along the cylinder axis (i.e. thrust direction) between the datum and load direction. The datum is defined as the projection of the gravity direction onto the plane.
member.remarks: Until gravity direction is definable in the domain, a default of -z is assumed. If this is found to be parallel to the cylinder axis a fall back direction of -y is assumed.

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.Materials.MaterialProperties.RelativePermittivityTable.RepairPermittivityColumnValues
member.summary:
Method to repair tables which have been mistakenly created with Permittivity quantities (a quantity type which represents absolute permittivity) instead of Ratio quantities (correct type for relative permittivity). Such tables may exist in files which were created after bug 628286 was introduced, but before it was fixed. In these files, the quantities have the correct value for the relative permittivity ratio, just stored with the wrong quantity type and unit.
This method should be called once for each permittivity table after resume. If the table is already valid, this will do nothing.

member.summary: Determine if modal analysis in Analyse stage is pre-stress or not. A "Pre-stress" simulation has at least one boundary condition (force, support, non zero displacement) and at least one fixed support.
member.param: Used to determine if conditions are compatible with the current stage
member.returns: If modal analysis is pre-stress
member.remarks: Requirement for Pre-stress : 1. at least one pre-stress BC (loads, gravity, non zero displacement), 2. at least one acting fixed support (fixed support or zero displacement)

member.name: F:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.BaseEntityEquality.MaxDepth
member.summary: Protect against infinite recursion when comparing cyclic data structures.
member.remarks: The depth is arbitrary; pick a number that suits you.

member.name: T:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.IEntityCollection`1
member.summary: An unordered set of entities.
member.typeparam: The specific type of entity. Must be a reference type that is assignment-compatible with .
member.remarks:
At runtime, each instance is owned by the property of an evaluation inside SpaceClaim. Entity storage has been implemented this way in order to integrate with SpaceClaim's undo-redo mechanism with the minimum hassle.
Unfortunately, the consequence of this design is that retrieving instances has at least O(N) time complexity, where N is the number of instances in the current project. This is because the only reliable way to find entities in SpaceClaim is to recursively walk the evaluation hierarchy from the project's root part. Thus the simple act of getting the associated with a particular can require a full walk through the entire part hierarchy. Consequently we must do everything we can to minimize the number of times that we go back to SpaceClaim for entities.
This interface has been designed to make it easier to use the entity storage system more efficiently. Its creation was prompted by the realization that many common operations were exhibiting O(N^3) [sic] time complexity using the previous incarnation of . This cubic time scaling was destroying performance for even modestly-sized projects.

member.name: T:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.Accessors.PropertyAccessor
member.summary: Reads and writes a property of an . The property is identified using the . member.summary: Gets or sets a string representing the path from the to the property being accessed. The path can be a single property identifier ("Foo") or a multi-part path with the individual property identifiers separated by dots ("Foo.Bar.Baz").

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.Accessors.PropertyAccessor.ToSerializable(Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.Accessors.PropertyAccessor)
member.summary:
Creates a single string encoding the and the . This string can subsequently be passed to to create a new instance containing these two values.
Note: This method makes no attempt to verify that the property of the current matches . The property is completely ignored here.
member.returns: A single string capturing the and values.

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.Accessors.PropertyAccessor.TryFromSerializable(System.String)
member.summary:
Creates a new instance of using the values of and encoded in the parameter.
Note: The property is not changed by this method. The caller is responsible for mapping the to an instance.
member.param: A string created by that encodes the pair of and .
member.returns: A new instance if the supplied was valid, otherwise returns to indicate failure.

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.Accessors.PropertyAccessor.TryGetValue(System.Object@)
member.summary: Attempts to read the value of the property indicated by the using as the root object.
member.param: The value returned by the final property in the , or if anything went wrong.
member.returns: Returns if the read succeeded, or if the read failed for any reason.

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.Accessors.PropertyAccessor.TrySetValue(System.Object)
member.summary:
Attempts to write the supplied to the property indicated by the using as the root object.
If the runtime type of the supplied does not match the type of the target property, conversion will be attempted:
If the property is of type and the parameter is of type , the value will be wrapped with . This simplifies updates to physics model properties such as .
Alternatively, if the supplied parameter supports then will be used to try to match the type of the value to the type of the property.
If type conversion fails then this method will return .
When the target property is read-only and the property path is multi-level, special steps are taken to force the update:
The object that is hosting the target property is cloned.
The read-only property of the cloned object is updated using reflection.
The cloned object is assigned to the parent.
If any step fails then this method returns .
member.param: The value to write to the property.
member.returns: Returns if the write succeeded, or if the write failed for any reason.

member.name: T:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Nominal.Persistence.SerializationSurrogateBase
member.summary: A base class for .
member.remarks: This class exists so we can define shared static property without getting caught be the rather tricky C# behavior where a static property on a generic class is not shared between specializations. If the logging design is changed and a static logger is no longer required then this base class can be eliminated. For more information on static properties in generic classes, see: https://rules.sonarsource.com/csharp/RSPEC-2743

member.name: P:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Nominal.Persistence.SerializationSurrogateBase.IssueLogger
member.summary: Gets a value representing a that can be used for logging persistence issues. This property is permitted to be .
member.remarks: We're using a static property here because serialization surrogates are created directly by SpaceClaim and so have no opportunity to inject a logger instance before SpaceClaim asks the surrogate to perform serialization and deserialization actions. We need the surrogate to be able to log any issues that occur during these actions and so we need to provide a way to log issues that doesn't require constructor injection. We could use a service locator pattern, but just putting the logger on a static property involves the smallest number of collaborators. A disadvantage of the static property approach is that it makes it harder to parallelize persistence operations and unit tests.

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Nominal.Persistence.SerializationSurrogateBase.SetIssueLogger(Ansys.Disco.Core.Issues.IIssueLogger)
member.summary: Sets a delegate for logging persistence issues.
member.param: A instance, or to disable issue logging.

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Nominal.Persistence.SerializationSurrogateForAttribute.GetSurrogatePairs(System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Queries an assembly for classes that have the and returns a list of the (surrogate => original) type mappings.
member.returns: A list of (surrogate => original) type mappings. The surrogate type is guaranteed to belong to the specified, but it's permissible for the original type to be defined in another assembly. Note also that it is possible for a single original type to have multiple surrogates. This situation can occur when an existing entity is modified in such a way as to require a new surrogate but the was not removed from the previous surrogate class. There is a unit test to prevent this situation from going undetected.
member.exception: If is .
The assembly contains one or more types that cannot be loaded.

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Suppression.PhysicsSuppressionAttributeTransfer.TransferSuppressedBodies(Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.Simulations.SimulationEntity)
member.summary: Retrieves, and clears the suppressed bodies in a document and transfers the suppression to the given simulation
member.param: The simulation to suppress bodies for

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Suppression.PhysicsSuppressionAttributeTransfer.RetrieveAndClearSuppressedBodies
member.summary: This method will find all of the bodies in the SpaceClaim document that have a "SuppressedAttribute" applied, and clear them as we do not use it in Discovery.
member.remarks: The "SuppressedAttribute" is a legacy flag that SpaceClaim would use to control the bodies transferred and applied to physics in other applications, such as AIM. ModelManager and Refine are still reading this attribute, and is it no longer required when we send geometry from Discovery. We therefore need to find all suppressed bodies, and clear the "SuppressedAttribute" from them, so that we control the suppression state in Discovery. Using the returned suppressed bodies, we can then set our own suppressed state on the simulation.
member.returns: A list of the suppressed bodies that were found.

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Suppression.PhysicsSuppressionAttributeTransfer.TransferSuppressedBodies(Ansys.Disco.Physics.Entities.Simulations.SimulationEntity,System.Collections.Generic.IList{SpaceClaim.IEvaluation})

member.param: The simulation to suppress bodies for

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.ValueObjects.ParameterSweeps.DrivingDimensionService.InvokeAfterCommandCompleted(SpaceClaim.Task)
member.remarks:
Using the we delay execution of tasks, such as raising a driving dimension events, until after the currently executing command has completed.
We do this to avoid the potential of the associated handlers attempting to grab the value related to the driving-dimension during the command and altering the current command properties; this occurs as to get the value the pull-tool is invoked in the background.
Alongside the above reason this delayed invoke makes the behavior between these standard events related to driving-dimensions and our internal domain events closer to one another, i.e. executed after the command has completed.

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.ValueObjects.Triad.InitialiseTriadWithNormalAsLocalX(SpaceClaim.Geometry.Direction)
member.summary: Initialize triad from normal Normal is used as the local x direction. The global z (or global y if the local x direction is Parallel to the global z direction) is projected onto the plane defined by the normal to determine the local y direction. The local z is the cross product of the local x and y.
member.param: Normal used to define orientation for new triad
member.returns: A triad whose orientation is determined by the normal

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.ValueObjects.Triad.InitialiseTriadWithNormalAsLocalY(SpaceClaim.Geometry.Direction)
member.summary: Initialize triad from normal Normal is used as the local y direction. The global z (or global x if the local z direction is Parallel to the global y direction) is projected onto the plane defined by the normal to determine the local z direction. The local x is the cross product of the local y and z.
member.param: Normal used to define orientation for new triad
member.returns: A triad whose orientation is determined by the normal

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.ValueObjects.Triad.InitialiseTriadWithNormalAsLocalZ(SpaceClaim.Geometry.Direction)
member.summary: Initialize triad from normal Normal is used as the local z direction. The global y (or global x if the local y direction is parallel to the global z direction) is projected onto the plane defined by the normal to determine the local y direction. The local x is the cross product of the local z and y.
member.param: Normal used to define orientation for new triad
member.returns: A triad whose orientation is determined by the normal

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Persistence.EntityUpdating.PlaceholderEntities.DeletePlaceholders(Ansys.Disco.Physics.Commands.Helpers.IDataAccess)
member.summary:
Deletes any whose is a known placeholder (e.g. or ). Such a is produced when a project file is resumed where the file contains one or more persisted entity definitions that could not be deserialized back to a valid instance, perhaps because the entity definition was corrupt in some way, or because the associated
method threw an exception, or because the entity type has been superseded and is no longer required.

member.name: T:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Persistence.PersistenceIssues
member.summary: Methods to construct user-facing messages for persistence issues.

remarks.para: I18N: These messages will need to internationalized, but that can wait until we've decided how persistence issues will be surfaced to the user.
REFACTOR: This is only intended to be a temporary location for these issue definitions. Once we understand the requirements better we can move the definitions elsewhere.

member.name: T:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Persistence.IRepresent`1
member.summary: Declares the capability to encode and decode an object of type . in a way compatible with SpaceClaim's XML serializer.
member.typeparam: The type of object that this class can persist.

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Persistence.IRepresent`1.CreateOriginal(System.Action{Ansys.Disco.Core.Issues.Issue})
member.summary: Creates a new instance of type using the information already stored in this object by a prior call to .
member.param: A delegate to call to report issues. The delegate may be called as many times as required. It is a calling contract violation for this parameter to be null.
member.returns: A new instance of the appropriate type. If a new instance cannot be created then information should be written to the supplied log and should be returned. It is acceptable for the implementation to throw an exception, but writing to the log is the preferred approach as this provides the most opportunity for meaningful user-facing error messages.

member.param: The object to copy information from. It is a calling contract violation for this parameter to be null.

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Utilities.DoubleParser.IsGroupingValid(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo)
member.summary: Determines whether the indicated string representation of a number uses the group separator character appropriately.
member.param: Optional numeric format information used to evaluate validity. If not specified or null, the default numeric format information of the current thread is used.
member.returns: True if the number grouping is valid and otherwise false. This method only evaluates the number with respect to number grouping. It doesn't evaluate whether the number itself is valid.

remarks.para: Application numbers may contain group separator characters that facilitate entering and interpreting a number (e.g., the commas in 1,000,000). The double.TryParse method ignores group separator characters. This results in "1,8" being interpreted as 18. It should be regarded as an error. However, "1,800" should be interpreted as 1800. In this example, the group separator character is a ",". Other cultures may use a different character.

Only the first group separator to the left of the decimal (if present) is examined. Other group separation characters are ignored. The intent of checking the validity is to prevent a typo being misinterpreted since for many cultures the decimal and group symbol characters are next to each other on a keyboard.

member.summary: Renders an to a single-string in CSV format.

The culture settings to use when formatting the export. If is , will be used (i.e. period for the decimal separator and comma for the field separator).
An to determine which unit to use when exporting each . If , the exporter will use the default base unit for each quantity type.
Contains the currently selected units for each column from the table view model.
When , the table rows will be sorted left-to-right. When , the rows will be returned in the order provided by the source .
member.returns: A string encoding the table's contents in CSV format, or an empty string if no table was provided.
member.remarks:
The supplied controls:
The decimal separator used for numbers (period vs comma).
The field separator (comma vs semicolon) used for CSV format.
The formatting of any cell value in the table.
The line separator always follows the current platform.

member.param: ID of the table to undo a change of.

Collection of values for each row, and indexes that each row was added at. When we undo, the rows at these indexes will be removed. Values are needed so we can create the redo action which will recreate the rows with the same values. Indexes are the positions that each row existed at after all were added.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.param: ID of the table to undo a change of.
Index of the row that was changed. When this undo action is applied the contents of the row at this index will be changed back to their previous values.
The row's values before it was changed, used by the undo action to revert the row to its previous state.
The row's new values after the change, used to construct the redo action which can then change the row back to its new state after this undo action is applied.

member.summary: Helper used by table undo/redo to save a copy of table row data that has been added to or removed from a table.

member.name: T:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Tables.TableRow
member.summary: This class provides access to a from the underlying while also providing a reference back to the parent .
member.remarks:
The purpose of this class is to allow us to change the property in response to user edits, something that would be impossible without capturing a reference to the parent because knows nothing of our class.
As a convenience, the method automatically brackets an edit with and and then sets to after the action has fired.

member.name: T:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Tables.TableQuantity
member.summary: A persistence-safe wrapper around .
member.remarks:
This type deliberately does *not* implement custom equality. Instances of this type are only equal if they are reference equal (i.e. the same instance). This type has mutable fields (to support XML serialization) and so equality becomes a bit slippery, particularly if we are expected to override .
If you want to compare two instance of this type for numerical equivalence, call and compare the results.

member.summary: Registers the specified for XML serialization when used as part of a .
member.remarks:
By default, will only serialize primitive types. In order to permit complex and custom types to be serialized, these types must first be registered with the .

member.summary: The format string for creating a DT1 chunk name. The `{0}` substitution is expected to receive the , but in theory is can be anything because we encode the TableId in the serialized XML and therefore don't need to parse the filename to extract the TableId.
member.remarks: WARNING: Do not use more than one `.` in the file name, otherwise SpaceClaim will raise strange errors (probably caused by confusion over file extension determination).

member.name: M:Ansys.Disco.Physics.Tree.TreeGrouping.DefineCodependentSiblingGroups(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String},System.Int32)
member.summary: Defines a set of sibling groups which are not created unless a certain number of them are present (sibling threshold). ex: given groups A, B, and C with a sibling threshold of 2: A will never appear unless B or C is also present. given groups A, B, and C with a sibling threshold of 3: A, B, and C must all be present for any of them to appear.
member.param: the list of groups that are codependent
the minimum number of siblings that must be present in order for them to appear
member.returns: returns false if the list includes groups that are not direct children of the same parent node or the sibling threshold is greater than the number of siblings listed or less than 2

function to build the group nodes
out value: returns whether any group successfully formed
